comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content:
From Wikipedia:

William Jay Gaynor (1849 – September 10, 1913) was an American politician from New York City, associated with the Tammany Hall political machine. He served as mayor of the City of New York from 1910 to 1913, as well as stints as a New York Supreme Court Justice from 1893 to 1909.

Early in his term, Gaynor was shot in the throat by James J. Gallagher, a discharged city employee. Gaynor remains the only New York City mayor to suffer an assassination attempt. ... Although Gaynor quickly recovered, the bullet remained lodged in his throat for the next three years. During his term as mayor, Gaynor was widely considered a strong candidate for Governor or President. Tammany Hall refused to nominate him for reelection to a second term, but after accepting the nomination from an independent group of voters, he set sail for Europe. Six days later, on September 10, 1913, Gaynor died suddenly from the lingering effects of the shooting. 

This photo was taken on the day of his funeral.

comment._content: I'm wondering why the right hand side of his house was all boarded up...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: This is 20, Eight Avenue, Brooklyn, in Park Slope. According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Jay_Gaynor and confirmed by the NYT report of his funeral query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B00E0D7123FE633A... which says the procession turned from Flatbush Avenue onto Eighth Avenue and past the Gaynor home.

comment.author: 33913611@N07
comment._content: By the way, the house pictured in the above comment is not the correct one. And, heck, I and many others sure as hell remember him! (or at least reading about him). There's that famous picture of his shooting, too, with Robert Todd Lincoln rushing to his side. A tragedy.

comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content: That may or may not be Lincoln. He has been identified as several different people. The New York World captioned him at the time as Edward J. Litchfield, a neighbor of Gaynor's. Ref: www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1967/6/1967....

comment.author: 33913611@N07
comment._content: Interesting ... the Litchfield mansion is right nearby this house, too.  They were quite a prominent family around here, so it does make sense they would hang out together.

Yeah, and then Robert Todd Lincoln mysteriously was at the side of William McKinley when he was assassinated.

What is with that?
